trans-unit.source: How to create a VNet using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to create a VNet using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: To create a VNet by using PowerShell, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VNet by using PowerShell, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: If you have never used Azure PowerShell, see [How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell](../articles/powershell-install-configure.md) and follow the instructions all the way to the end to sign into Azure and select your subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you have never used Azure PowerShell, see [How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell](../articles/powershell-install-configure.md) and follow the instructions all the way to the end to sign into Azure and select your subscription.

trans-unit.source: If necessary, create a new resource group, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: If necessary, create a new resource group, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, create a resource group named *TestRG*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, create a resource group named *TestRG*.

trans-unit.source: For more information about resource groups, visit [Azure Resource Manager Overview](../articles/resource-group-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about resource groups, visit [Azure Resource Manager Overview](../articles/resource-group-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Create a new VNet named *TestVNet*, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Create a new VNet named *TestVNet*, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Store the virtual network object in a variable, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Store the virtual network object in a variable, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] You can combine steps 4 and 5 by running **$vnet = New-AzureRmVirtualNetwork -ResourceGroupName TestRG -Name TestVNet -AddressPrefix 192.168.0.0/16 -Location centralus**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] You can combine steps 4 and 5 by running **$vnet = New-AzureRmVirtualNetwork -ResourceGroupName TestRG -Name TestVNet -AddressPrefix 192.168.0.0/16 -Location centralus**.

trans-unit.source: Add a subnet to the new VNet variable, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Add a subnet to the new VNet variable, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Repeat step 6 above for each subnet you want to create.
trans-unit.target: Repeat step 6 above for each subnet you want to create.

trans-unit.source: The command below creates the *BackEnd* subnet for our scenario.
trans-unit.target: The command below creates the *BackEnd* subnet for our scenario.

trans-unit.source: Although you create subnets, they currently only exist in the local variable used to retrieve the VNet you create in step 4 above.
trans-unit.target: Although you create subnets, they currently only exist in the local variable used to retrieve the VNet you create in step 4 above.

trans-unit.source: To save the changes to Azure, run the **Set-AzureRmVirtualNetwork** cmdlet, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: To save the changes to Azure, run the **Set-AzureRmVirtualNetwork** cmdlet, as shown below.
